derbies: London derbies vs Chelsea and West Ham United
6.playing_style: Historically strong attacking sides, with a focus on technical wingers and creative forwards.
fun_facts: Tottenham were the first British club to win a major European trophy, lifting the European Cup Winners’ Cup in 1963.
The modern Tottenham Hotspur Stadium is designed to also host NFL games and has one of the steepest stands in the Premier League.

8.playing_style: High-intensity, pressing football with quick transitions and passionate home support.
fun_facts: The anthem 'You’ll Never Walk Alone' is sung before every home match at Anfield.
Liverpool are one of Europe’s most successful clubs, with multiple European Cups/Champions League titles.

9.playing_style: Possession-dominant, positional football with intricate passing and high pressing.
fun_facts: Manchester City won a historic treble including their first Champions League title in the early 2020s.
The club was originally founded as St. Mark’s (West Gorton) before becoming Manchester City.

10.playing_style: Historically known for strong youth development and energetic, pressing football.
fun_facts: Southampton’s academy produced players like Alan Shearer, Gareth Bale and Theo Walcott.
The club’s nickname 'The Saints' comes from its origins as a church football team.

derbies: West London derbies vs Chelsea, QPR and Brentford
11.playing_style: Typically a technical, possession-based side, especially at home at Craven Cottage.
fun_facts: Craven Cottage is a historic riverside stadium right next to the River Thames.
Fulham reached the Europa League final in 2010 after a remarkable knockout run.

13.playing_style: Traditionally associated with hard work, strong defence and passionate support.
fun_facts: Everton were founding members of the Football League in 1888.
Dixie Dean once scored 60 league goals in a single season.

14.playing_style: Traditionally attacking, wing-focused football with late comebacks and strong home form.
fun_facts: The 'Class of 92' produced several club legends including Giggs, Scholes, Beckham and the Neville brothers.
Manchester United completed a famous treble in 1999, winning the league, FA Cup and Champions League.

derbies: Second City Derby vs Birmingham City
15.playing_style: Historically a traditional English club with strong home support and a mix of physical and technical play.
fun_facts: Aston Villa won the European Cup in 1982.
Villa Park is one of the most famous traditional football grounds in England.

derbies: London derbies vs Arsenal and Tottenham
West London derbies vs Fulham and Brentford
18.playing_style: Modern, flexible team often built around strong defence, transitions and big-game performances.
fun_facts: Chelsea have won the Champions League multiple times in the 21st century.
Didier Drogba scored in several major finals for Chelsea, becoming a true club icon.

derbies: North London Derby vs Tottenham Hotspur
London derbies vs Chelsea and West Ham
19.playing_style: Known for technical, passing football, particularly during the Wenger era.
fun_facts: Arsenal went unbeaten in the league in the 2003–04 season, earning the nickname 'The Invincibles'.
Before moving to the Emirates, Arsenal played at the iconic Highbury stadium.

20.playing_style: Massive home support, often associated with attacking football and high-energy games.
fun_facts: Alan Shearer, the Premier League’s all-time top scorer, is a Newcastle legend.
St James’ Park dominates the skyline of Newcastle and is located close to the city centre.

derbies: London derbies vs Tottenham and Chelsea
21.playing_style: Traditionally a working-class, gritty team with strong home support and famous academy products.
fun_facts: West Ham’s academy produced key members of England’s 1966 World Cup winning side.
The club won a major European trophy again in the 2020s, boosting its continental pedigree.

derbies: East Midlands derbies vs Nottingham Forest and Derby County
26.playing_style: Counter-attacking, high-intensity football, especially during their title-winning season.
fun_facts: Leicester City shocked the football world by winning the Premier League in 2015–16.
Jamie Vardy’s rise from non-league football to Premier League champion is one of the game’s best stories.

derbies: East Lancashire Derby vs Blackburn Rovers
27.playing_style: Previously associated with organised, direct football and strong defensive structure.
fun_facts: Burnley have been English champions in the pre-Premier League era.
Turf Moor is one of the oldest football grounds still in regular use.

derbies: Black Country Derby vs West Bromwich Albion
29.playing_style: In modern times, known for compact defending and quick breaks through wide players.
fun_facts: Wolves were one of the dominant English teams in the 1950s.
They were involved in high-profile floodlit friendlies that helped inspire European competitions.

derbies: M23 Derby vs Brighton & Hove Albion
51.playing_style: Energetic, often built around quick wingers and strong home atmosphere.
fun_facts: Crystal Palace’s rivalry with Brighton is unusually intense given the distance between the clubs.
Selhurst Park is known for its loud and colourful fan section, especially the Holmesdale stand.

derbies: South coast rivalries vs Southampton, Portsmouth and Brighton
52.playing_style: Under Eddie Howe, known for brave, attacking football even against bigger clubs.
fun_facts: Bournemouth reached the Premier League for the first time in their history in 2015.
Vitality Stadium is one of the most compact stadiums to host Premier League football.

derbies: Steel City Derby vs Sheffield Wednesday
62.playing_style: Physical, direct and intense, with notable overlapping centre-backs under Chris Wilder.
fun_facts: Bramall Lane has been used for both football and cricket historically.
Sheffield United were one of the early powers of English football in the late 19th and early 20th century.

derbies: East Midlands Derby vs Derby County
63.playing_style: Historically famous for disciplined, clever football under Brian Clough.
fun_facts: Nottingham Forest famously won the European Cup twice under Brian Clough.
The City Ground is located right by the River Trent.

71.playing_style: Historically tough, physical side; in the Bielsa era known for extreme high pressing and attacking football.
fun_facts: Leeds were a dominant English side in the late 1960s and early 1970s under Don Revie.
Marcelo Bielsa became a cult hero for the club’s return to the Premier League with a unique playing style.

78.playing_style: Modern, brave build-up football from the back with heavy use of structured possession.
fun_facts: Brighton moved from the old Withdean Stadium to the purpose-built Amex Stadium in 2011.
In recent years Brighton became a model club for smart scouting and data-driven recruitment.

derbies: West London derbies vs Fulham and QPR
236.playing_style: Modern, analytics-heavy club with a mix of direct play, pressing and clever set-pieces.
fun_facts: Brentford are widely cited as one of the most data-driven clubs in European football.
The club moved from the historic Griffin Park to their new Gtech Community Stadium in 2020.

fan_culture: Huge nationwide fanbase with strong ultra culture in the Südkurve.
Home matches at Allianz Arena are almost always sold out.
iconic_seasons: 2012-13 treble: Bundesliga, DFB-Pokal and Champions League under Jupp Heynckes.
2019-20 treble with Hansi Flick and a dominant Champions League campaign.
famous_wins: 7–1 aggregate win over Barcelona in the 2012-13 Champions League semi-final.
8–2 win against Barcelona in the 2019-20 Champions League quarter-final.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing the 1999 Champions League final to Manchester United after leading until stoppage time.
Losing the 2011-12 Champions League final on home soil at Allianz Arena to Chelsea on penalties.
trivia: Allianz Arena can light up in different colors depending on who is playing.
Bayern are known as the 'Recordmeister' for holding the record of most German league titles.

fan_culture: Home to the famous 'Yellow Wall', the largest standing terrace in Europe.
Known for one of the loudest and most passionate fanbases in Germany.
iconic_seasons: 2010-11 and 2011-12 back-to-back Bundesliga titles under Jürgen Klopp.
1996-97 season, winning the Champions League against Juventus.
famous_wins: 4–1 win over Real Madrid in the 2012-13 Champions League semi-final first leg.
3–1 victory over Juventus in the 1997 Champions League final.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing the 2012-13 Champions League final to Bayern Munich at Wembley.
Missing out on the 2022-23 Bundesliga title on the last day of the season.
trivia: Signal Iduna Park regularly exceeds 80,000 in attendance.
BVB is short for 'Ballspielverein Borussia 09 e.V. Dortmund'.

fan_culture: Backed by Red Bull, the club is controversial among traditional German fans.
Despite being young, the club established itself quickly in European competitions.
iconic_seasons: 2016-17: finishing second in their debut Bundesliga season.
2019-20: reaching the Champions League semi-final.
famous_wins: 3–0 away win over Tottenham Hotspur on aggregate in the 2019-20 Champions League round of 16.
Bundesliga wins over Bayern Munich that announced them as serious title challengers.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing DFB-Pokal finals before finally winning the cup.
Falling short in the Bundesliga title races to Bayern.
trivia: The club was effectively built on the license of a fifth-division side, SSV Markranstädt.
Their rapid rise from regional football to Champions League semi-finalists happened in about a decade.

fan_culture: Club originally founded by Bayer pharmaceutical workers.
Often labeled as a 'company club', but has a loyal core fanbase and ultras.
iconic_seasons: 2001-02 season, finishing runners-up in the league, cup and Champions League ('Neverkusen').
Later unbeaten league campaigns under Xabi Alonso.
famous_wins: Champions League semi-final win over Manchester United in 2001-02.
Big Bundesliga wins over Bayern and Dortmund in title-chasing seasons.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing three major titles in 2001-02, including the Champions League final vs Real Madrid.
Multiple seasons finishing second in the Bundesliga without securing the title.
trivia: The nickname 'Neverkusen' comes from repeatedly finishing second in big competitions.
BayArena is considered one of the more modern, compact stadiums in Germany.

fan_culture: Strong traditional fanbase with a lot of nostalgia for the 1970s golden era.
Home atmosphere at BORUSSIA-PARK is known for choreographies and chanting.
iconic_seasons: 1970s period with multiple Bundesliga titles and deep European runs.
Champions League group stage wins against modern European giants.
famous_wins: Big European wins in the UEFA Cup (now Europa League).
Heavy home victories over Bayern Munich in different eras.
heartbreaking_moments: Narrowly missing out on more European titles in the 1970s.
Relegation battles in certain periods after the golden era.
trivia: The nickname 'Die Fohlen' ('The Foals') references the young, energetic team style of the 1970s.
They share the 'Borussia' name with Dortmund, both named after a local brewery / the Latin word for Prussia.

fan_culture: One of the most passionate local fanbases in Germany.
The Revierderby vs Dortmund is one of the fiercest derbies in Europe.
iconic_seasons: 2000-01: almost winning the Bundesliga, losing the title in the last seconds to Bayern.
Champions League semi-final run in 2010-11.
famous_wins: 4–4 comeback vs Dortmund in 2017 after being 4–0 down.
Victories in European competitions against strong opposition.
heartbreaking_moments: The 'Meister der Herzen' season (2000-01) where they lost the title in stoppage time.
Recent relegation from the Bundesliga after financial and sporting collapse.
trivia: The club is named after the Schalke district in Gelsenkirchen.
Veltins-Arena has a retractable pitch and roof and is used for major events beyond football.

derbies: Lower Saxony derbies vs Hannover 96 and Eintracht Braunschweig
fan_culture: Club backed by Volkswagen with a relatively small but loyal fanbase.
Home to both successful men's and women's teams; the women's side is a European powerhouse.
iconic_seasons: 2008-09: winning their first ever Bundesliga title with Džeko and Grafite.
2014-15: finishing second and winning the DFB-Pokal.
famous_wins: 5–1 win over Bayern Munich in 2009 with a Grafite backheel goal.
3–2 Champions League win over Manchester United in the group stage.
heartbreaking_moments: Struggling in relegation battles after title-winning highs.
Failing to build long-term consistency after strong seasons.
trivia: Volkswagen Arena is located right next to the VW factory.
The club's wolf mascot fits both the city name and the nickname 'Die Wölfe'.

fan_culture: Known for incredible away support across Europe.
Historic tifos and choreographies in European nights.
iconic_seasons: 1979-80: winning the UEFA Cup.
2017-18: winning the DFB-Pokal vs Bayern Munich.
2021-22: winning the Europa League.
famous_wins: 3–1 win vs Bayern in the 2018 DFB-Pokal final.
Europa League wins over Barcelona and West Ham in 2022.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing the 1960 European Cup final 7–3 to Real Madrid, still remembered for attacking football.
Relegation battles in the 1990s and 2000s.
trivia: The club's eagle symbol is one of the most iconic in German football.
Frankfurt's European nights are considered among the loudest in the competition.

derbies: Swabian derbies vs Freiburg and other regional clubs
fan_culture: Strong regional identity in Baden-Württemberg.
Known for producing and developing talented young players.
iconic_seasons: 2006-07: winning the Bundesliga under Armin Veh.
Early 1990s title wins in unified Bundesliga.
famous_wins: Title-clinching wins in 2007 against direct rivals.
European nights in the Champions League and UEFA Cup.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations from the Bundesliga despite a big fanbase.
Narrow survival battles on the last matchday in multiple seasons.
trivia: The club name includes the year of foundation: 1893.
Stuttgart have one of the largest stadiums in Germany when fully expanded.

derbies: Rhein Derby vs Gladbach and Leverkusen
fan_culture: One of the most loyal and humorous fanbases in Germany.
The live goat mascot 'Hennes' is brought to home games.
iconic_seasons: 1963-64: first champions of the new Bundesliga.
Strong Bundesliga finishes in the 1970s and 1980s.
famous_wins: Historic wins over European clubs in UEFA competitions.
Derby wins over Mönchengladbach and Leverkusen that mean a lot to fans.
heartbreaking_moments: Multiple relegations despite huge support.
Missing out on more titles during strong eras.
trivia: Köln were the first official Bundesliga champions in 1964.
The goat mascot is named after former coach Hennes Weisweiler.

fan_culture: Represents the capital city Berlin in German football.
Olympiastadion atmosphere peaks during big derbies and evening games.
iconic_seasons: Late 1990s and early 2000s European qualification runs.
Seasons challenging near the top half of the table.
famous_wins: Historic home wins in European competitions.
Derby victories against Union Berlin.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations despite big-city backing.
Missed chances to establish themselves as a stable European-level club.
trivia: The club's nickname 'Die Alte Dame' means 'The Old Lady', similar to Juventus.
Olympiastadion also hosts the DFB-Pokal final every year.

fan_culture: Known for a very loyal and family-friendly fanbase.
Home stadium sits directly along the Weser river.
iconic_seasons: 2003-04: winning the Bundesliga and DFB-Pokal double.
Multiple Champions League appearances in the 2000s.
famous_wins: Historic wins over Bayern Munich during title races.
UEFA Cup games with high scorelines and dramatic comebacks.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegation from the Bundesliga after decades in the top flight.
Narrowly missing out on titles during strong eras.
trivia: Claudio Pizarro became a cult hero and club legend over multiple spells.
The Nordderby vs Hamburg is one of Germany's classic rivalries.

fan_culture: Large and traditional fanbase with deep roots in German football.
Known for intense derbies, especially vs St. Pauli.
iconic_seasons: Late 1970s and early 1980s: multiple league titles and European success.
1982-83: winning the European Cup (Champions League).
famous_wins: European Cup final win vs Juventus in 1983.
Big domestic wins during their golden era.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegation in 2018, ending their status as the last ever-present Bundesliga club.
Play-off failures when trying to get promoted back to the top flight.
trivia: HSV famously had a 'Bundesliga clock' in the stadium tracking their uninterrupted time in the league — until relegation.
Their blue, white, black colors are based on the clubs that merged to form HSV.

derbies: Local Baden derbies vs Stuttgart and Karlsruhe
fan_culture: Respected as a 'smart' club that overachieves with limited resources.
Strong community connection and support in a smaller market.
iconic_seasons: Multiple top-half finishes and European qualifications under Christian Streich.
DFB-Pokal final appearance in the 2020s.
famous_wins: Home wins vs bigger clubs like Bayern and Dortmund.
European victories that showcased their tactical discipline.
heartbreaking_moments: Missing out on trophies in finals and deep cup runs.
Relegations followed by immediate promotion back up.
trivia: Christian Streich is one of the longest-serving coaches in the Bundesliga.
The club is known for developing players that later move to bigger teams.

rivals: Regional clubs like Freiburg and Stuttgart
fan_culture: Frequently criticized as a 'plastic club' due to billionaire backing.
Still built a loyal local support in the region.
iconic_seasons: 2008-09: surprise autumn champions in their first Bundesliga season.
2017-18: qualifying directly for the Champions League under Nagelsmann.
famous_wins: High-scoring wins vs established Bundesliga clubs.
Champions League group stage performances vs top European teams.
heartbreaking_moments: Missing out on trophies despite strong squads.
Struggling to gain wider acceptance among traditional fans.
trivia: The club rose from lower leagues to the Bundesliga in an extremely short time.
Julian Nagelsmann became one of the youngest head coaches in Bundesliga history at Hoffenheim.

fan_culture: Known for fighting spirit and overachieving compared to expectations.
Strong regional support within Bavaria.
iconic_seasons: 2014-15: finishing fifth in the Bundesliga and qualifying for the Europa League.
Successful survival seasons where they punched above their weight.
famous_wins: Shock wins against Bayern Munich and other top clubs.
UEFA Europa League performances vs larger European teams.
heartbreaking_moments: Close relegation battles decided in the last matchdays.
Losing key players after strong seasons.
trivia: Despite modest resources, Augsburg established themselves as a stable Bundesliga club.
WWK Arena is one of the smaller stadiums in the league by capacity.

fan_culture: Mainz has one of the friendliest and most humorous fan cultures in Germany.
The club is proud of being the starting point for coaches like Klopp and Tuchel.
iconic_seasons: First-ever promotion to the Bundesliga under Jürgen Klopp.
Europa League qualifications under Tuchel and later coaches.
famous_wins: Important wins over big clubs like Bayern and Dortmund, often with pressing masterclasses.
Decisive matches to avoid relegation on final days.
heartbreaking_moments: Missing out on promotion in dramatic fashion before finally going up.
Inconsistent spells leading to late-season pressure.
trivia: Both Jürgen Klopp and Thomas Tuchel started their top-flight coaching careers at Mainz.
The '05' in the name refers to the founding year 1905.

fan_culture: One of the most unique and passionate fan cultures in Germany.
Fans helped rebuild and renovate the stadium themselves.
iconic_seasons: First promotion to the Bundesliga in club history.
Qualifying for European competitions and even the Champions League spots.
famous_wins: Derby wins vs Hertha BSC that shocked the traditional order in Berlin.
Home victories over European contenders in the Bundesliga.
heartbreaking_moments: Long years in lower leagues before promotion.
Close calls in relegation and promotion play-offs.
trivia: Union fans once donated blood to help finance the club ('Bluten für Union').
The stadium is known for its forest setting and standing terraces.

fan_culture: Juventus has one of the largest fanbases in Italy and worldwide.
Traditionally associated with winning mentality and 'result first' football.
iconic_seasons: 1984-85: winning the European Cup (Champions League) for the first time.
1995-96: winning the Champions League again vs Ajax.
2011-12 to 2019-20: era of domestic dominance with nine straight Serie A titles.
famous_wins: Champions League final win vs Liverpool in 1985.
Champions League final win vs Ajax on penalties in 1996.
Multiple title-deciding wins against Inter and Milan.
heartbreaking_moments: Heysel disaster (1985) overshadowing the European Cup win.
Losing several Champions League finals, including vs Barcelona and Real Madrid.
Calciopoli scandal and relegation to Serie B in 2006.
trivia: Juventus is owned by the Agnelli family, who also control Fiat.
The club switched from pink shirts to black and white stripes in the early 1900s.

derbies: Derby della Madonnina vs AC Milan
fan_culture: Curva Nord provides intense support and choreography at San Siro.
Inter has a global fanbase and a strong presence in Asia and South America.
iconic_seasons: 1960s 'Grande Inter' era under Helenio Herrera, winning multiple European Cups.
2009-10: winning the historic treble (Serie A, Coppa Italia, Champions League) under José Mourinho.
Recent title-winning seasons breaking Juventus' domination.
famous_wins: Champions League semi-final wins over Barcelona in 2010.
Champions League final win vs Bayern Munich in 2010.
Derby wins vs AC Milan in Scudetto-deciding races.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing decisive title races on the final day of the season.
Ups and downs after the treble with periods of chaos and transition.
Champions League final losses in more recent years.
trivia: Inter is the only Italian club never to have been relegated from Serie A.
The snake 'Biscione' is a historic symbol of both Inter and the city of Milan.

derbies: Derby della Madonnina vs Inter Milan
style_of_play: Famous for elegant yet effective football
Historic use of pressing and zonal marking under Arrigo Sacchi
fan_culture: Curva Sud is known for its passionate choreographies at San Siro.
AC Milan has a massive international fanbase, particularly in Asia.
iconic_seasons: Late 1980s and early 1990s dominance in Italy and Europe under Sacchi and Capello.
2002-03 and 2006-07 Champions League winning campaigns.
2021-22: Scudetto win after an 11-year drought.
famous_wins: 4–0 win vs Barcelona in the 1994 Champions League final.
Champions League final win vs Juventus in 2003.
Title-deciding derby victories vs Inter.
heartbreaking_moments: 2005 Champions League final collapse vs Liverpool in Istanbul.
Near misses in Serie A during periods of transition.
Decline after 2010 leading to fewer European appearances.
trivia: Despite being an Italian club, AC Milan uses the English spelling 'Milan'.
Milan and Inter share the same stadium, San Siro (Stadio Giuseppe Meazza).

notable_managers: Diego Maradona (as leader on pitch, not manager)
style_of_play: High-intensity pressing under Sarri and Spalletti
fan_culture: One of the most passionate and emotional fanbases in Europe.
The city of Naples lives and breathes football, especially during title races.
iconic_seasons: 1986-87 and 1989-90: Maradona-era Scudetti.
2017-18: 91-point season under Sarri, narrowly missing the title.
2022-23: First Scudetto in over 30 years, with Osimhen and Kvaratskhelia starring.
famous_wins: Scudetto-clinching wins during the Maradona years.
Champions League wins vs Liverpool and other top sides.
Key victories against Juventus in title races.
heartbreaking_moments: Post-Maradona decline and financial collapse.
Near misses in Scudetto races vs Juventus.
European exits despite strong performances.
trivia: The stadium was renamed Stadio Diego Armando Maradona in honour of their greatest legend.
Napoli is the main club of southern Italy with huge regional significance.

fan_culture: Roma fans are known for their incredible choreography and emotional support.
The Derby della Capitale vs Lazio is one of the most intense derbies in the world.
iconic_seasons: 2000-01: winning the Scudetto with Totti, Batistuta and De Rossi.
Deep Champions League runs, including a semi-final in 2017-18.
2021-22: winning the inaugural UEFA Europa Conference League under Mourinho.
famous_wins: 3–0 comeback vs Barcelona in the 2017-18 Champions League quarter-final.
Title-clinching win vs Parma in 2001.
Derby wins vs Lazio that defined entire seasons.
heartbreaking_moments: Narrowly missing out on Serie A titles in mid-2000s vs Inter.
Losing key players in their prime due to financial constraints.
Champions League heartbreaks despite heroic comebacks.
trivia: Francesco Totti spent his entire career at Roma and is considered 'Il Capitano'.
The club crest features a she-wolf referencing the legend of Romulus and Remus.

derbies: Derby della Capitale vs AS Roma
style_of_play: Strong use of forwards and wing-backs
fan_culture: Very passionate and vocal ultras in the Curva Nord.
The Derby della Capitale is central to the club’s identity.
iconic_seasons: 1999-2000: winning the Scudetto and Coppa Italia double.
Late 1990s: big investments and star players leading to multiple trophies.
Seasons where Immobile won the Capocannoniere (top scorer) title.
famous_wins: Title-deciding matches in 1999-2000.
Supercoppa Italiana victories against Juventus.
Derby wins vs Roma celebrated like trophies.
heartbreaking_moments: Missing out on titles despite big spending in late 1990s.
Financial issues and squad break-up after the success era.
Losing crucial derbies and European matches.
trivia: Lazio is older than Roma and originally a multi-sports club.
The eagle mascot 'Olimpia' is sometimes flown inside the stadium before matches.

derbies: Lombardy derbies vs Brescia, Inter, Milan and others
style_of_play: Overlapping center-backs and fluid shapes under Gasperini
fan_culture: Bergamo is a smaller city but with very passionate fans.
Atalanta's recent rise made them a neutral fan favourite in Europe.
iconic_seasons: 2019-20: reaching the Champions League quarter-finals in their debut campaign.
Multiple top-four Serie A finishes under Gasperini.
Winning European silverware in the 2020s.
famous_wins: Champions League wins over Valencia and other big clubs.
High-scoring wins vs top Serie A sides like Milan and Napoli.
Europa League knockout victories.
heartbreaking_moments: Late Champions League elimination vs PSG in 2020.
Losing Coppa Italia finals.
Near misses in the Scudetto and top-three races.
trivia: Atalanta are often called 'the best-run club in Italy' for their scouting and player development.
They frequently outscore almost every other team in Serie A.

derbies: Tuscan derbies vs Empoli and other regional clubs
fan_culture: Florence is a proud and emotional football city.
Fiorentina fans have a special rivalry and tension with Juventus.
iconic_seasons: Late 1990s with Batistuta and Rui Costa starring.
Serie A and European campaigns where they challenged the top clubs.
Recent deep runs in European competitions and domestic cups.
famous_wins: Big wins over Juventus, especially at home.
European nights vs top clubs.
Cup semi-final and final victories.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegation and bankruptcy issues in early 2000s.
Losing key stars due to financial issues.
Heartbreaking cup and European final defeats.
trivia: Batistuta is one of the most iconic one-club legends in Fiorentina history.
The purple kit is one of the most unique in European football.

notable_managers: Ernest Erbstein (as part of Grande Torino era)
style_of_play: Modern era often built on defensive solidity
fan_culture: Torino fans are deeply attached to the memory of the 'Grande Torino' team.
The club has a strong identity despite living in Juventus' shadow.
iconic_seasons: 1940s 'Grande Torino' era dominating Italian football.
Early 1970s Scudetto and strong league finishes.
Europa League qualification campaigns.
famous_wins: Title-winning matches in the 1940s and 1970s.
Derby wins vs Juventus that are still celebrated decades later.
heartbreaking_moments: Superga air disaster in 1949 that killed nearly the entire Grande Torino team.
Relegations and financial problems in later decades.
trivia: The Superga tragedy is commemorated every year by fans and the club.
The maroon ('granata') shirt is one of the most traditional in Italy.

style_of_play: Recently more modern pressing and build-up under Thiago Motta
fan_culture: Bologna has a proud football tradition despite fewer recent trophies.
Supporters are very attached to the club’s history.
iconic_seasons: Pre-World War II Scudetti.
Modern-era pushes for European qualification.
Uplifting period under Mihajlović despite his illness.
famous_wins: Historic domestic wins when they were champions of Italy.
Important home wins vs bigger sides in modern Serie A.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations from Serie A.
Falling short in races for European spots.
Emotional period surrounding Mihajlović's health battles.
trivia: Bologna have more Serie A titles than many people realize (seven).
The stadium Dall'Ara is one of the classic Italian football grounds.

rivals: Regional rivalries with other northern clubs
style_of_play: Scouting-based model with frequent player trading
fan_culture: Smaller but loyal fanbase in the Friuli region.
Club is respected as a smart scouting team.
iconic_seasons: Champions League qualification in mid-2000s.
Top-four finishes under Guidolin with Di Natale scoring heavily.
famous_wins: High-scoring games vs big clubs.
European qualification deciders.
heartbreaking_moments: Missing out on Champions League group stages in qualifiers.
Falling from top-four level back to mid-table.
trivia: Antonio Di Natale is one of Serie A’s all-time top scorers.
Udinese is part of a multi-club ownership model including clubs like Watford in England (in some eras).

style_of_play: Often pragmatic in modern Serie A
fan_culture: Genoa is one of Italy’s oldest clubs with very traditional support.
Derby della Lanterna vs Sampdoria is extremely passionate and colourful.
iconic_seasons: Early 1900s dominance in Italian football.
Europa League qualifications in modern times.
Promotion seasons back to Serie A.
famous_wins: Derby wins over Sampdoria.
Upset wins vs bigger Italian clubs.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations and yo-yo years between Serie A and B.
Missing out on European football due to licensing issues in some seasons.
trivia: Genoa is technically the oldest football club in Italy, founded in 1893.
They share the Luigi Ferraris stadium with Sampdoria.

fan_culture: Ultra groups create spectacular displays in the stands.
Derby vs Genoa is central to their identity.
iconic_seasons: 1990-91: winning their only Serie A title.
1991-92: reaching the European Cup (Champions League) final vs Barcelona.
famous_wins: Title-deciding wins in 1990-91.
European Cup semi-final wins.
Derby della Lanterna victories.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing the 1992 European Cup final in extra time vs Barcelona.
Relegations and financial struggles in later decades.
trivia: Sampdoria was formed by a merger of two older clubs, Sampierdarenese and Andrea Doria.
Their kit design is one of the most distinctive in football.

derbies: Derby della Scala vs Chievo Verona
fan_culture: Passionate local fanbase with strong regional identity.
Derbies vs Chievo carried a lot of meaning when both were in Serie A.
iconic_seasons: 1984-85: winning their only Serie A title against all odds.
famous_wins: Victories over big clubs during their title-winning season.
Home upsets vs top Serie A teams.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations and financial issues.
Battles to stay in Serie A decided on final matchdays.
trivia: Their 1984-85 Scudetto is considered one of the biggest surprises in Serie A history.
Verona is famous worldwide due to Shakespeare’s 'Romeo and Juliet'.

style_of_play: Winning mentality and late comebacks in big games
fan_culture: Massive worldwide fanbase and huge commercial power.
The Bernabéu crowd demands attacking football and trophies.
Known for 'remontadas' – dramatic comebacks on Champions League nights.
iconic_seasons: 1950s: Di Stéfano era dominating Europe.
2001–02: Champions League win with Zidane’s volley vs Leverkusen.
2013–14: La Décima – 10th European Cup.
2016–18: Three consecutive Champions League titles under Zidane.
famous_wins: Champions League final vs Juventus (4–1) in 2017.
4–0 win vs Barcelona at Camp Nou in 2015 (various Clásicos).
Comebacks vs PSG, Chelsea and Manchester City in 2021–22 Champions League.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing league titles on the final day of the season.
Defeats to Barcelona in heavily one-sided Clásicos.
Some early Champions League exits in the early 2000s galáctico era.
trivia: Real Madrid was named FIFA Club of the 20th Century.
The all-white kit gave rise to the nickname 'Los Blancos'.
The club’s crest originally featured a simpler design without the crown.

style_of_play: Heavy use of La Masia academy graduates
fan_culture: Slogan 'Més que un club' (More than a club) is central to identity.
Strong Catalan identity and political symbolism.
Camp Nou crowds appreciate creative, attacking football.
iconic_seasons: 2008–09: Sextuple under Guardiola (La Liga, Copa del Rey, Champions League, etc.).
2010–11: Peak tiki-taka team with Xavi–Iniesta–Messi.
2014–15: Treble with MSN (Messi–Suárez–Neymar).
famous_wins: 5–0 vs Real Madrid in 2010.
6–2 vs Real Madrid at the Bernabéu in 2009.
6–1 vs PSG in 2017 Champions League comeback.
Champions League final wins vs Manchester United (2009, 2011).
heartbreaking_moments: Champions League collapses vs Roma (2018) and Liverpool (2019).
Financial crisis and Messi’s departure in 2021.
trivia: La Masia is one of the most famous academies in world football.
Barça’s original kits were similar colours to the Swiss club FC Basel.
The club is owned by its members (socios), not a private owner.

style_of_play: Very strong mentality in knockout ties
fan_culture: Known as the club of the people and working-class Madrid.
The Metropolitano atmosphere is loud and intimidating for opponents.
Fans identify with the underdog, 'never say die' identity.
iconic_seasons: 2013–14: Winning La Liga and reaching Champions League final.
2020–21: Another La Liga title under Simeone.
Multiple deep Champions League runs in the 2010s.
famous_wins: La Liga title-clinching matches vs Barcelona and Real Madrid.
Eliminating Barcelona and Bayern Munich in Champions League semi-finals.
Victories over Real Madrid in Copa del Rey and league derbies.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing Champions League finals vs Real Madrid in 2014 and 2016.
Conceding late equalisers/defeats in big European matches.
trivia: Originally founded as a branch of Athletic Club (Bilbao).
Nickname 'Los Colchoneros' comes from old mattress patterns similar to their stripes.

style_of_play: Historically very strong in European knockout ties
fan_culture: Ramón Sánchez Pizjuán is famous for its noise and pre-match anthem.
Seville derby vs Betis is one of the most intense local derbies in Spain.
Fans have a strong emotional identity with the club’s European success.
iconic_seasons: Mid-2000s back-to-back UEFA Cup wins.
2013–2016: Europa League dominance under Unai Emery.
Recent Europa League wins in the 2020s.
famous_wins: Multiple Europa League finals victories.
Big wins vs top clubs in Europe while on Europa League runs.
Derby wins vs Real Betis remembered for years.
heartbreaking_moments: Falling short in La Liga title races.
Group-stage exits from the Champions League.
Occasional relegation battles despite strong squads.
trivia: Sevilla are record winners of the UEFA Cup/Europa League.
The club anthem, sung a cappella by fans, is one of the most iconic in Spain.

derbies: Derbi de la Comunitat vs Villarreal
style_of_play: Varied: from defensive and counter-attacking under Benítez, to possession-based styles in other eras
Strong use of wingers and creative midfielders
fan_culture: Mestalla is one of the loudest stadiums in Spain.
Fans have high expectations due to the club's history.
Supporters have had tense relationships with certain owners and boards.
iconic_seasons: Early 2000s: Two La Liga titles and two Champions League finals.
2018–19: Winning Copa del Rey vs Barcelona in club’s centenary season.
famous_wins: Champions League wins vs big clubs like Leeds, Arsenal and Barcelona.
Copa del Rey final win over Barcelona in 2019.
Title-clinching games under Rafa Benítez.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing Champions League finals in 2000 and 2001.
Financial problems and instability in the 2010s.
Relegation battles despite strong fanbase.
trivia: Valencia’s bat symbol is tied to the city’s coat of arms.
The planned new stadium (Nou Mestalla) has been delayed for many years.

derbies: Derbi de la Comunitat vs Valencia
style_of_play: Mix of Spanish passing style and pragmatic defending
Very strong in European competitions for a small town club
fan_culture: Villarreal is a small town, but the club regularly plays in Europe.
Fans take pride in punching above their weight against giants.
iconic_seasons: 2005–06: Champions League semi-final run.
2010s and 2020s: Regular European appearances.
2020–21: Winning the UEFA Europa League vs Manchester United.
famous_wins: Europa League final win on penalties vs Manchester United (2021).
Champions League wins vs Bayern Munich and Juventus.
Top-four finishes in La Liga.
heartbreaking_moments: Riquelme's missed penalty vs Arsenal in 2006 semi-final.
Relegation in 2011–12 despite strong squads.
trivia: Nicknamed 'Yellow Submarine' due to the yellow kit and Beatles reference.
The club represents a town of only around 50,000 people.

style_of_play: Traditionally very direct, with modern tactical updates
fan_culture: Uses a unique Basque-only player policy (Basque-born or formed in Basque academies).
San Mamés is known as 'La Catedral' of Spanish football.
Strong regional identity and pride.
iconic_seasons: 1980s league titles under Javier Clemente.
2011–12 Europa League run under Marcelo Bielsa.
Various Copa del Rey finals in the modern era.
famous_wins: Supercopa wins vs Barcelona and Real Madrid.
Europa League victories vs Manchester United in 2012.
Historic home wins against Spanish giants at San Mamés.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing multiple Copa del Rey finals.
Coming close to European trophies but falling just short.
trivia: One of only three clubs never relegated from La Liga (with Real Madrid and Barcelona for long periods).
The Basque-only policy makes their success even more remarkable.

style_of_play: Heavy use of academy players from Zubieta
fan_culture: Strong Basque identity and focus on youth development.
Fans appreciate fluid, attacking football.
iconic_seasons: Early 1980s La Liga titles.
Recent seasons with regular European qualification.
2020–21: Copa del Rey win in an all-Basque final vs Athletic.
famous_wins: Basque derby wins vs Athletic.
European wins vs big clubs in Europa League.
Strong performances against Real Madrid and Barcelona at home.
heartbreaking_moments: Narrowly missing titles in certain seasons.
Copa and European exits after promising runs.
trivia: Their academy, Zubieta, is one of Spain’s best talent factories.
The 2020 Copa final vs Athletic was played a year late due to the pandemic.

style_of_play: Attractive attacking football in recent years
Big emphasis on wide play and overlaps
fan_culture: Betis fans are known for the phrase 'Viva el Betis manque pierda' (Long live Betis even if they lose).
Benito Villamarín can be extremely loud, especially in the Sevilla derby.
iconic_seasons: La Liga title in 1934–35.
Copa del Rey wins, including 2004–05 and 2021–22.
Recent European qualification seasons under Pellegrini.
famous_wins: Derby wins vs Sevilla.
High-scoring away win vs Real Madrid (historic results).
Cup wins at packed Benito Villamarín.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations to Segunda despite big fanbase.
Losing derbies in dramatic fashion.
Narrow misses on Champions League qualification.
trivia: The club colours and style give Betis a big following even outside Seville.
Joaquín played into his 40s and is a club legend and TV personality.

derbies: Galician Derby vs Deportivo La Coruña
style_of_play: Technical and possession-based in some eras
Counter-attacking with quick transitions in others
Often built around Iago Aspas in the modern era
fan_culture: Local Galician identity is important for Celta fans.
The rivalry with Deportivo is central to the club’s story.
iconic_seasons: Early 2000s European runs.
2016–17 Europa League semi-final run under Berizzo.
Great escapes from relegation thanks to Aspas.
famous_wins: Big wins vs Barcelona and Real Madrid at Balaídos.
Knockout victories in Europa League runs.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations after promising spells.
Europa League semi-final loss vs Manchester United in 2017.
trivia: Iago Aspas is considered 'Mr. Celta' and a club saviour in multiple seasons.
Galicia’s rainy, coastal climate creates unique match conditions.

style_of_play: Historically varied: often defensive and counter-attacking
fan_culture: Espanyol see themselves as the alternative to FC Barcelona in the city.
The Derbi Barceloní is emotionally charged despite club size differences.
iconic_seasons: Copa del Rey wins in the 20th century.
UEFA Cup final runs in the late 1980s and 2000s.
Promotions back to La Liga after relegations.
famous_wins: Derby victories vs Barcelona.
UEFA Cup runs with big knockout wins.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing UEFA Cup finals on penalties.
Multiple relegations despite big city status.
trivia: The nickname 'Pericos' means 'parrots' in Spanish/Catalan.
The club has moved between different stadiums, now settled at RCDE Stadium.

style_of_play: Very strong at home, especially in difficult conditions
fan_culture: El Sadar is one of the toughest away grounds in Spain.
Fans are known for their noise and constant support.
iconic_seasons: Top-four finish and Champions League qualification in the 2000s.
Copa del Rey final appearances.
famous_wins: Home wins vs Barcelona and Real Madrid.
Cup upsets vs bigger sides.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations after strong seasons.
Losing Copa finals or semi-finals.
trivia: The name 'Osasuna' comes from the Basque language and means 'health' or 'strength'.
Pamplona is famously known worldwide for the running of the bulls (San Fermín festival).

derbies: Catalan derbies vs Barcelona and Espanyol
style_of_play: Heavily data- and analytics-influenced recruitment (City Football Group link)
fan_culture: Fast-growing fanbase thanks to recent success.
Local Catalan pride and underdog mentality vs Barça.
iconic_seasons: First-ever promotion to La Liga in 2017.
Remarkable title-challenge seasons in the 2020s.
famous_wins: Big wins vs Barcelona and Real Madrid in La Liga.
High-scoring matches that grabbed international attention.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegation after early La Liga seasons.
Narrow misses for European qualification in some campaigns.
trivia: Girona is part of the City Football Group network.
They became one of La Liga’s surprise packages with an attacking style.

derbies: Le Classique vs Olympique de Marseille
style_of_play: Heavy focus on individual star quality
Attacking style with high pressing in some eras
fan_culture: Ultras from the Virage Auteuil and Boulogne stands create an intense atmosphere.
Club identity changed heavily after Qatari ownership and superstar signings.
Le Classique vs Marseille is the biggest rivalry in French football.
iconic_seasons: 2012–13: First title of the QSI era with Ibrahimović.
2014–15: Domestic quadruple (Ligue 1, Coupe de France, Coupe de la Ligue, Trophée des Champions).
2019–20: Champions League final vs Bayern Munich.
Multiple seasons with 90+ league points dominance.
famous_wins: 6–1 vs Barcelona in 2017 (first leg of UCL round of 16).
Multiple big wins vs domestic rivals Lyon and Marseille.
High-scoring Champions League nights vs Bayern, Barcelona, Real Madrid and others.
heartbreaking_moments: The 6–1 loss vs Barcelona at Camp Nou in 2017 after a 4–0 first-leg lead.
Losing the 2020 Champions League final vs Bayern Munich.
Several Champions League exits after dramatic comebacks by opponents.
trivia: PSG is a relatively young club compared to other European giants.
Qatar Sports Investments transformed PSG into one of the richest clubs in the world.
The Eiffel Tower has often been incorporated into PSG marketing and kit designs.

style_of_play: Can shift between direct physical football and technical attacking play.
Bielsa era brought high pressing and vertical football.
fan_culture: Some of the most passionate supporters in Europe.
Stade Vélodrome is famous for its noise, flares and choreography.
Marseille see themselves as the people’s club of France.
iconic_seasons: 1992–93: Won the Champions League vs AC Milan.
Late 1980s and early 1990s domestic dominance under Bernard Tapie.
2010 Ligue 1 title under Didier Deschamps.
famous_wins: 1–0 vs AC Milan in 1993 Champions League final.
Historic wins over PSG in Le Classique.
Run to the Europa League final in 2018.
heartbreaking_moments: Match-fixing scandal in 1990s leading to relegation.
Losing European finals and falling short in title races.
Inconsistent eras with regular coaching changes.
trivia: Marseille is the only French club to have won the Champions League.
The city’s port and multicultural identity feed into the club’s character.
The OM crest often features a star for the 1993 UCL title.

style_of_play: Strong focus on technical midfielders and attacking full-backs.
Dominant possession and quick combinations during their 2000s dynasty.
Heavily reliant on youth academy products (Académie OL).
fan_culture: The Derby vs Saint-Étienne is one of the most heated in France.
Fans enjoyed a golden era of seven straight titles in the 2000s.
Supporters take pride in OL’s academy and attacking football tradition.
iconic_seasons: 2001–2008: Seven consecutive Ligue 1 titles.
Consistent Champions League quarter-final runs in the 2000s.
2019–20: Champions League semi-final appearance.
famous_wins: Champions League wins vs Real Madrid, Bayern, and other giants.
Derby victories vs Saint-Étienne.
Big domestic wins during their title streak.
heartbreaking_moments: Falling away from title contention after PSG’s rise.
Near misses in European competitions in the 2000s.
Recent struggles and inconsistency despite strong talent.
trivia: Juninho is widely regarded as one of the best free-kick takers in history.
OL Women (OL Féminin) are one of the most successful women’s teams ever.
The club’s modern stadium is a regular host for finals and big matches.

derbies: Derby de la Côte d’Azur vs Nice
style_of_play: Historically very attacking, with strong emphasis on youth development.
Quick transitions and high-scoring games in the Jardim era.
Fluid attacking systems with overlapping full-backs and creative 10s.
fan_culture: Smaller local fanbase due to the size of Monaco, but big international following.
Known for developing and selling world-class players.
Away support often louder than home, given stadium characteristics.
iconic_seasons: 2003–04: Champions League finalists vs Porto.
2016–17: Ligue 1 title, Champions League semi-final; Mbappé’s breakout season.
Multiple domestic titles in the 80s and 90s.
famous_wins: Champions League wins vs Real Madrid and Chelsea (2004).
Eliminating Manchester City and Borussia Dortmund in 2017 UCL.
Title-clinching performances vs PSG in 2016–17.
heartbreaking_moments: Losing the 2004 Champions League final.
Relegation and financial troubles before returning to the top.
Being forced to sell key players after big seasons.
trivia: Although they play in French leagues, Monaco is a separate principality.
Stade Louis-II is known for its distinctive architecture and location.
The club has launched the careers of many French legends.

style_of_play: Explosive transitions with pacy wingers and forwards.
Strong balance between youth development and smart recruitment.
fan_culture: Fans are proud of upsetting bigger clubs with lower budgets.
Nord derby vs Lens is extremely emotional.
Supporters value hard-working, collective teams over individual stars.
iconic_seasons: 2010–11: Ligue 1 and Coupe de France double under Rudi Garcia.
2020–21: Surprise Ligue 1 title win under Galtier, finishing ahead of PSG.
famous_wins: Winning away at PSG during the 2020–21 title race.
Key Champions League group-stage wins vs bigger clubs.
Derby victories vs Lens.
heartbreaking_moments: Selling stars like Hazard after big seasons.
Financial and sporting instability in certain periods.
Early European exits after promising domestic campaigns.
trivia: Lille’s 2021 title win is seen as one of the biggest shocks in modern Ligue 1.
The club has been a launchpad for many Premier League stars.

style_of_play: High-intensity, brave football in the modern era.
Flexible back-three system under Franck Haise.
Strong wing-back play and overloads in wide areas.
fan_culture: Lens is known for some of the best fans in France.
The small mining town identity creates a working-class, united atmosphere.
Derby du Nord vs Lille is huge for both communities.
iconic_seasons: 1997–98: First-ever Ligue 1 title.
1998–99: Strong European campaigns.
2020s: Top-of-the-table finishes and return to European competition.
famous_wins: Title-clinching matches in the late 1990s.
Home wins vs PSG and other giants in recent seasons.
Derby victories vs Lille celebrated massively in the town.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations and financial struggles.
Narrowly missing out on the title or Champions League places in recent years.
trivia: The club’s colours reference the local mining heritage (blood and gold).
Bollaert can host more people than the town’s population.

derbies: Breton derbies vs Nantes, Guingamp and other Breton clubs
style_of_play: Modern, attacking style with emphasis on wide players.
Strong use of academy graduates mixed with smart signings.
Good pressing structure under recent coaches.
fan_culture: Breton identity is important to Rennes fans.
The ultras create strong atmospheres in big European and derby games.
Supporters are proud of the club’s academy production.
iconic_seasons: 2018–19: Coupe de France win vs PSG on penalties.
Recent seasons with regular European qualification.
famous_wins: Coupe de France final vs PSG in 2019.
Europa League wins vs bigger clubs.
Derby wins vs Nantes.
heartbreaking_moments: Near misses in European qualification or cup runs.
Talented academy players leaving early for bigger clubs.
trivia: Rennes have one of the best youth academies in France.
The club has become a consistent top-half/Ligue 1 European contender in recent years.

derbies: Derby de la Côte d’Azur vs Monaco
legends: Hatem Ben Arfa (short but iconic spell)
style_of_play: Modern era: controlled build-up with strong defensive structure.
Earlier eras: more open, technical football.
Recently focused on being hard to beat, with quick counters.
fan_culture: Nice has a passionate but smaller local fanbase on the Riviera.
Derbies vs Monaco and big games vs Marseille are key dates.
Ownership projects have tried to push Nice towards regular European football.
iconic_seasons: 1950s: Multiple Ligue 1 titles.
2016–17: Surprising title challenge and top-three finish under Favre.
famous_wins: Victories vs PSG and Monaco in modern seasons.
Historic title-winning matches in the 1950s.
heartbreaking_moments: Inconsistent projects despite strong investment.
Near misses in Champions League qualification spots.
trivia: Allianz Riviera is also used for rugby and international events.
Nice has produced and hosted many technically gifted players over the years.

derbies: Breton derbies vs Rennes and other clubs
style_of_play: Historically known for 'jeu à la nantaise' – fluid, collective passing football.
Focus on movement, combinations and youth development.
fan_culture: Fans are proud of their historic style of play identity.
Strong regional connection to western France.
Beaujoire can be very loud in big games and relegation battles.
iconic_seasons: 1994–95: Legendary title season with only one league defeat.
Multiple titles in the 1960s, 70s and 80s.
famous_wins: Title-clinching matches in their 1990s golden era.
European wins against stronger sides in the past.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegations after years of success.
Modern-era struggles to stay in Ligue 1.
Tragic loss of striker Emiliano Sala in 2019.
trivia: Nantes’ identity is one of the most 'purist' football philosophies in France.
Many World Cup-winning French players started at Nantes.

style_of_play: 2011–12 title side: compact defensive block plus efficient counter-attacks.
Often pragmatic, adapting to opponents and squad strengths.
fan_culture: Supporters are proud of their underdog 2012 title win ahead of PSG.
Derbies vs Nîmes are heated and emotional.
iconic_seasons: 2011–12: Shock Ligue 1 title win with Olivier Giroud as top scorer.
famous_wins: Title-clinching games in 2012.
Wins vs PSG and other giants during the title season.
heartbreaking_moments: Relegation battles in other years.
Struggles to replicate the title-winning level after selling key players.
trivia: Their 2011–12 title is one of the biggest surprises in modern Ligue 1.
The club has a reputation for discovering late-blooming talents.
